In this town on the 9th ipst Mrs. Sally, wife ofMr. Heman Osborn, aged 36---inserted last week the ] wife of Mir. Harmon Osborn

 In Hadley Mass. May 26, the venerable and pous Mrs. Sybil Smh, ,aged 1Ol years, month, and days. Her parents were Mir. Daniel Warrington and Mrs. Betsey his wife; the number of her children were l9 of whom 15 lived be the heads of families. Mrs. Smith was born in Colchester, Conn., April IS, 1726 was early dedicated to God in baptism, and favor had themselves known by happy experience, the transforming power ofthe gospel She, however,con-

 nued stranger to personal religion, till she had the charge of family when in the time of general stu, r.dity, she was suddenly and powerfully impressed with her guilt and danger; her distress continued ny months, and issued, there is to doubt in her cordial submission to the humblng of saliva ton through Jesus Christ It was some time after she had bccome happy in view of the government of God, and tic method of redeeming mercy, disclosed ir the Bbie before she expressed or even dared to cherish vction of her sinfuness was deep and overwhel- ming, while her joy in God was unutterable. After much sefexaminaton, prayer, and dgent study of the fsss bseome sd aewsSe 1gs r fsr away sad all aS 80 %1ea aaaadea fo ssh ut na s ample to the last day and last hour of nt. Thus for seventy years, she was known and honoieT asa follower of the Lamb, and member of his visible fam lily on earth Not an individual, is presumed in the circle of her acquaintance, has any doubt of the gen. uness of her piety. Her mental powers were more than ordinary; and she retained them, in remarka ale degree, till within two three of her last years Though her mind became then enfeebed, she enjoyed the use of her reason to her dying day. Her memmo ry richly stored with hymns and passages which to Dea Elijah Smith, of Belchertown, who died A. D. 177O, and at last Mir. Reuben Smith South Iadley who died A. h. 1797. One brother and three sisters survive herr of whom is 96 years of age, one 92, 90, 85. The total of their ages, added to hers, is 464 years The whole number of her decen- dants is children, all of whom lived until the young est had attained the age of 57-8 of them liV I.-c H. ~l. nx,l children, and of the fifth generation; making total of 266, of whom 2O4 are now living. Many of her prosterity professors of religion of whom are with Foreign Missions, under the direction of the A. mercan Board "As the days of a tree the days of my people. They shall bring forth fruit in old age; thy grave in full age as shock of corn cometh in its | season."
BREED

Has been determined on by large number of lib- eral gentlemen of that city, and to be edited by the subscriber, with an associate of distinguished literary attainnents. It is to be DAILY MORNING PAPER,de- voted principally to commerc and manufactures but including politics, literature and whatever else that may be interesting to intelligent men of business Ad- vertisments for the theare of lottery tickets, and of business to be transacted the Sabbath will be cluded. It is intended that the Shipping List shall not be surpassed in the country, especially will more thorough attention be paid to Eastern vessels than is usual in Ncw-YorlS. price current will be inserted as arrangements can be made to furnish one, which can be relied upon. The price is the same other New-York papers, $1O--A Journal will be is- sued SEMI-WEEKLY, containing the principal matter, at $4 To companies subscribing six papers seventh will be included gratis

 The gentlemen who have determined upon the es- tabshment of this paper have not done 1t with view to any pecuniary advantage. They have higher motive and one which has long interested the feelings of moral and religious men in Boston, New-York and other cities They ready to sacrifice money, to any amount which may be required. But it IS evi- dent that accomplish any valuable purpose wide circulation must be had. good subscription list has been obtained in NewYork, but the enterprise IS new in it's character and has to contend with many and powerful obstacles. To overcome these, no labor nor expense the part of the projectors or the Ed- tors will be spared. And they invite the hearty CO., of the country and its civil and literary institutions upon tlc basis of Christian religion and sound mor- ality.

 The publication will be commenced as soon as the details of preparation can be arranged And 1t IS re- uuested that names should be returned soon without York. DAVID HALE.

Iaisscovse riik Kss Msriosr,gA IeiieF to the cd. itors of the National InselligenccF, from a cores- csng of the increase of trade and intercourse between the Western country and the territories be- yondt:-

 FoRr OsAGE, May 10, 1897.

 "The Commissioners are just setting out for two months tour in the great prairies, to finish marking out the road" to New Mexico, upon the survey and examination that completed last fal- After the return, the Commissioners will make their final and full report of the Board which will be acc companied by very complete maps and chGrts and will, presume, be minute in its details and las I hope) satisfactory and interesting in all it's results- This work should have been entirely completed and reported last year, before the meeting of Congress but has been unavoidably delayed by the very unex- pected refusal of the Mexican Government to co-op- crate promptly in the measure.

 "TO judge from the preparations making should incline to think that the trade from this section of the Union to New Mexico, must be still increasng- Several fitting out, and will be on the road in few weeks; these, am informed, larger and better equipped, and carry out more value of merchandise than any which have heretofore gone to New Mexico. l have doubt this trade will con- tinue to increase till it settles down into well ganized and quite important branch of commerce, profitable to all concerned in it, and we'll worthy of the protection and fostering of the General Gov ernment, which doubt not it will receive in due time.o

 The Yearly Meeting of Friends commenced at Portsmouth, N. H. on Saturday, and was held on Sunday, at Newport, where it continued until We'd nesday. Anna Braithwaite and other celebrated Friends from England, attended the meeting.

 A Rev. gentleman (says the Providence Journal who has statedIy preached in this town to a large congregation for the last thnysx years has during that period, united in marriage 1Ge0 persons.

 The "Banksan Medal" of the London Horti- cultural society has been awarded to gentleman of Albany for barrel of American apples, embracing twenty varieties, forwarded to the society last winter Col. Leavenworth passed through Franklin, Missou- ri, on the 29th, of April, his way to the River Platte, to examine and fix place for military cantonment and the 1st of May four companies of United States Infantry arrived at Franklin, by water and proceeded on to join him.

The June No. Of "The Casket" which is publish ed monthly at this office, contains view of the COT particular dscrpon of that celebrated scene, so beau tifully illustrated in Walter Scor's novel of The Heart of Midi Lothian" Also aview of QUEBECk, propriate narrative of it's ro:aanuc and picturesque scenery copied from Sl'ne:, Tour. Nos. 20, 2l, P and g of '"the scho. of Flora" md an original song, from the pen of our adm,rei conespo9dsnt lent number abound with original Tales, Essays and P6- etry, diversified by anecdote and useful miscellany.

 Enlarged and improved as the Casket' has recent ly been it now presents the lovers of literature one of the cheapest compendums of Miscellany to be found in the United States the cngrasings (three &C.,

FROM cLERGYMEN OF VARIOUS DENOMINATIONS.

 From the Rep. D.. Gri6in.-"I esteem Dr. Scots Family Bible, a e%anenty ny calculated to promote the for me to read daily the Notes and Observations with out becoming wiser and better man.'

 Rer. Asa Eaton, pastor of Christ Church, Boston. -" It is TREASURE WHICH EVERY FAMILY OUGHT TO POSSESS. For the success your undertaking you have my best wishes and fervent prayers"

 Rep. Dr. Joshua Bates, President ef M;ddlebury Coiiege.-" Sir, pleased with your proposals for publishing Scott's Family Bible, and sincerely wish you in your undertaking. have doubt that it will be well patronized by the religious public.'

 Rep. Daniel Shap pastor of the Sd Baptist Church, Boston.' The more it is read by pious Christians, the more extensive will be it's circuation.'

 Reu. Dr. Ba,d,oin, late pastor of the 2d Baptist Church, Boston, ""I feel free to say that in my esti nation it deservedly ranks among ables and best Commentaries. An the leading doctrines of Chris tanity as professed and maintained by many of the most eminent Reformers, are in judgment very hap pily illustrated and enforced"

 Reu Dr.. Dana-" Dr. Scott's Commentary, has merited and obtained distinguished popularity. The spirit which pervaes the work is excellent. It IS the meek, aectionate, healing yet faithful, spirit of the Gospel.

 Reu Joseph Emerson, Author of the Epanselical Primer" Six editions of this great work have been published in this county-I have had considerable opportunity to examine and compare specimens of all these six editions, and decidedly of opinion, that most people would greatly prefer ARNfSTRONG'S EDITION, now publishing in Boston. As the fold is octave, the volumes are not nearly 50 large the quarto editions; but the paper is finer and winter; the execution handsomer the print to appearance nearly as large; and it be turned to the light with much less nconyenence, 1t may perhaps be read with equal and pleasure. It has the advantage of be ing cheaper, less cumbersome, and more elegant.

 "ARMSTRONG'S EDITION, therefore, is the one which, most highly recommend for the use of families.  Editors of papers who favor us with exchange wall confer particular obligation by inserting the a. bove once in their respective papers.

Of power'-we refer tO legislative caucussos,--we were conending for rather than for mensares, and were therefore acting in direct opposition to prOies sOns previously advanced. True, we had partiaity for certain men, and most ardenly desired their cess, at the late election but this pariay based upon the measures which these individuals would advocate in cOniradistnction to their opponents In supporting the national administration, and opposing the unprincpled faction,-made up from all parties, whig and tory, democrat and federal, bucktail and Cntonian, federation and ant-toleratou,-whicb has recently been "Organized' against it, have been accused of acting upon party" instead of "no par ty" principles. But in the pursuit of both these sures, we have done that which we have ever meant to do; never gave even an intimation that we meant to act contrary to the we have pur- sucd

 In the commencement of a volume of our pa- per, we can see no reason why we should apologize for any supposed alterations in general political course the past year, give any pledges to the course we shall pursue the coming year. We shall oppose the elevation of Gen. Jackson and his harpagons to the highest offices in the country- and so far the course of Mir. Adams and his cabi net is marked by attachment to domestic rather than foreign interests, so long shall yield them hearty support. We shall oppose legislative Caucusses, and every other similar which has tendency to destroy free and unbiased eec- ton; and so long present state constitution and the rights which it guarantees the people, respected by our state administration, so long will it command confidence, and receive from us cheerful and liberal support.

 Manutacturers' Meeting in Boston-A large & high ly respectable meeting of gentlemen friendly to the encouragement of domestic manufactures held in Boston the fifth inst. Many able addresses were made to the meeting, supporting the object for which they assembled & calculating in clear & forci bic manner the importance of strictly adhering to, and warmly supporting, the "American System' of pro- tecting industry, in preference to that of other country. We have given the speech of Mir. Otis entire; not because we consider it better than many others that delivered; but because Mir. Otis IS gentleman of age, of wealth, of experience, and has spent his life thus far in the midst of great commercial people; and consider opinions advan- ced by such entitled to great degree of credit The people of the Ncw-Engand Middle and Western States, have very deep interest in the question now pending, whether Congress shall establish such sys shall give safety and stability to American indus try, whether shall be left entirely to the mercy of older manufacturing and commercial nations, who strenuously persist in te adoption of such exclusively protect the industry and capital of their own people-whether shall be driven to the cessy of sending gold to England to purchase wool len goods,-a country which refuses to receive any important article of American growth industry, with the exception of Cotton-or whether such protec- ton shall be given to manufacturers shall ble them to supply our market with the article.

 This question is to be decided in the Senate at the next session of Congress- Whether the bill which passed the House in May last will pass the Senate is extremely doubtful. The measure is now, and has been, tavourite one with MT. Adams and Mir. Clay, and entirely devoid of principle the efforts made by the "Jackson Combination" that no means will be left untried to defeat the bi The people however will be heard upon this subject; and already has spirit of enquiry gone abroad among the rcemen of certain states deeply interested in the manufactu ring question: who were recently opposed to Mr. Ad- ams that augers we'll not only for the American Sys tem" but also for the reelection of present Chief Magistrate.

 The editor of the Hartford Times, paper of con- siderable circulation, and possessing good share of political influence abours almost necessarily to i'm press upon the public mind the opinion that Mr. Ad is unworthy of rust in the great republican family, and that Gen. Jackson, his competitor, possesses al- most infinitely more worth and patriotism than he does; and predicts that the time will shortly come when this will be owned and acknowledged by the republicans of Connecticut. Possibly should we make counter statement to this we should find many who would consider us worthy of credit, Mir. Wells finds to support his theory But the opinions of great men will ever be taken in preference either his ours, we shall give below certain extracts from late New York American relative to the comparative merits of Messrs. Adams and Jackson.-We shall begin with MT. Adams.

 Gen. Washington'S opinion of /. Q. AdamS.-In 1797, when he Minister Penipotentiary to Portu- gal, Washington sad-"I give it as my decided opin- "on that MT. Adams is the most valuable public char "actcr we have abroad, and there remains no doubt Con my mind that he will prove himself the abes of "all our diplomatic corps" At that period it will be rccollected that our foreign ministers, were Rufus King John Marshall, Chief Justice of the U. S. Su- preme Court c. c. Pinckney, and Eibridge Gerry. Mr. Adams first appointment as minister he received from President Washington in 179l.

 In 1907, he was appointed by President Jefferson, xstn;ser to Russia and how entirely he enjoyed the con6dence and friendship of Presidents Madison and :. fo Sav-hnt we shall

son President wNs tho single oiTeufnsanec that had shaken his faith, and made him fear that the Amcr can Republic was soon to follow the fate of an others and fall under military rule."

 We cannot, says the American, better comment up- on this opinion (which has not been denied, because it is well known that even though might be hoped to bear down the testimony to its truth of any n dividual even though respectable as GOv Coles, there are many others to whom Jefferson had expres- sed the apprehensOns,) than by copying the marks of the Richmond Whig, in relation to it.

 "We do (says the Whig) publish this opinion of Mir. Jefferson, with the hope the expectation of proselytism. We know too much of party spirit and party feelings to expect it. Fools to be vnced-the men of sense who support General Jack son, do it in the face of facts; in defiance of thou sand evidences of his unftness, imposing and overwhelming, than can be the opinion of Thomas Jefferson any other man. They have gone too far recede-or they infatuated to change, tho one should come from the dcad But there is a nu- class of meutrals, who have yet to de- csion between Adams and Jackson. Is not Mir. Jef. ferson's opinion entitled to weight and consideration with them Did not his information embrace the hs tory of the whole human family? Was not his experi and observation, the longest, the closest, the most profound and philosophical of any who has taken interest in the destinies of country? Will any doubt his devotion his country and human liberty every where Was not he the great apostle of Repub Lcanism Mir. Jefferson respected Gen. Jackson for his personal merts and honoured him for his public servicesyet did he think and say, and at time when he longer had any personal interest how the affairs of the United Stateswere managed, tat he oeced the prospect o his election to tue Presidency, bad omem tor the durability te Repblic---as evidence that the American people, like their Republican predecessors in Europe, ready to after military lender, and surrender their liberties to the first aspiring mili- tary chieftan who could dazzle them with the lustre of his glory"

 "The Litclfeld County Post, due some three weeks since, has not yet come to hand 1t has been suggest ed that there certain strctures on correspon- dent in that number of the paper, and the modest Ed itor has withheld his sheet in consequence. This we cannot believe of the courteous genenan-somc Post Master must have hooked it-or some thief must have broached the mailbag and laid violent hands that paper, the most valuable thing in it. Mir. Smith withhold his papers from us No indeed. He is sand to be the most honest man in all Litchfcd County devoid of low-cunnng, deceit hypocrisy, and all of evil-dvested of even that cursed bane which engendereth strife, ycleped party spirit We consider him one of the tarest specimens of Adams democra- cy--a strange congregation of WOrdS-v1negar and o--but Mr. Smith is honest. We wish he would send another paper in place of the missing, solen stray cd, lost number.'

 The above was published in the Hartford Times on the 4th inst Our readers will recolect the remarks upon the article in paper of the 7th. Inthe Times of the 11th the above is called "cvil request for missing number of the Pos," and the editor accuses of every thing vile, for noticing his "reques in the manner we did, In the Times of the 18th Mir. Wells boasts bravely of having detected in "pal pablo fasehood" for having asserted i'll our hrst mo- tice of h..i that the Post received by him, and the article in question read,' &1c: We did not con- sder the above civil paragraph" any proof the contrary rather considered it direct attempt at picking an editorial quarrel with It surely car res very much of that appearance the face of the it, and did act counter to human weakness in viewing it in that hgh especially since we were warn- ed some two or three months ago, that immediately after the close of the Legislature, attack would be made upon usby this paragon ofrepublcan excellence. We considered it impossible that the editor of the Times alone should miss hspaper, when all rsheets sent to Hartford covered in the same envelope; and we also considered it almost impossible that the whole package should be lost. Such however ap- pears to have been the fact; and had the editor reality cvilly requested' the number in question, 1t would have been forwarded and no {" ink shed' upon the subject.

 We again very civilly'' request Mir. Wells to con fine his attacks upon political questions which may be debated candidly. The common sense of the people is neither pleased nor eded by such indefinite attacks upon the character, political moral, of each other as individuals. Show wherefore you have dis- carded us from tho republican family point out our political heresy; give your views of political rectitude place your standard and stick to it, and we will either contend with you, publicly acknowledge your political infallbility.

 The Hat Shop of Messrs B. Kilbourn x Go. in the vicinity of this village, took fire Saturday night last fortunately the fire discovered and extin- guished without any material damage. We mention this circumstance because reports have gone abroad that the whole establishment destroyed; and the loss they have suffered by the fire, between $lOO and $200 is sufficient, without loss of custom from an impression that their business must be suspended for a season. The damage is nearly repaired, and their business will not be suspended on account oft.

 The Supreme Court of Errors commenced its an- nua session in this town Tuesday last. Present, Justices Hosmer, Dagget, Peters, and Lanman We know nothing of the quantity or importance of the business which will occupy the attention of the Court

SHARON, JUNE 12, 1897.
HE NETWORK JOURNAL OF COMMERCE,

The Albany papers state that Strang, who has been some time in prison, the murderer of Mir. Whipple has acknowledged his guilt. The whole transaction exhibits one of the most determined acts of wifu mur der we ever heard of Intent on his victim, this mon- ster in human shape had previously practsed firing at ,G2rk through glass, ascertain whether ball would glance upon this substance. The evening which he committed the murder, he called at several public pla- ces probably to destroy any suspicion which might at tach to him after the contemplated act he then took his rife, climbed upon shed which gave him com manding view ofhs victim, andaeok the fatal aim A r ter having fed to some dasResahd secured hisrife he returned to the vicinity Mir. Whippe's house, and was empanneled of the coronersjury which sat ,.on the murdered body! Strang also accuses Mrs. Whippe of being accessary to the act whether to n- crease the misery he has already brought upon the family, or because such is the fact We have not been able to learn.

full articles.headline: BREED
full articles.article:
In this town on the 9th ipst Mrs. Sally, wife ofMr. Heman Osborn, aged 36---inserted last week the ] wife of Mir. Harmon Osborn

 In Hadley Mass. May 26, the venerable and pous Mrs. Sybil Smh, ,aged 1Ol years, month, and days. Her parents were Mir. Daniel Warrington and Mrs. Betsey his wife; the number of her children were l9 of whom 15 lived be the heads of families. Mrs. Smith was born in Colchester, Conn., April IS, 1726 was early dedicated to God in baptism, and favor had themselves known by happy experience, the transforming power ofthe gospel She, however,con-

 nued stranger to personal religion, till she had the charge of family when in the time of general stu, r.dity, she was suddenly and powerfully impressed with her guilt and danger; her distress continued ny months, and issued, there is to doubt in her cordial submission to the humblng of saliva ton through Jesus Christ It was some time after she had bccome happy in view of the government of God, and tic method of redeeming mercy, disclosed ir the Bbie before she expressed or even dared to cherish vction of her sinfuness was deep and overwhel- ming, while her joy in God was unutterable. After much sefexaminaton, prayer, and dgent study of the fsss bseome sd aewsSe 1gs r fsr away sad all aS 80 %1ea aaaadea fo ssh ut na s ample to the last day and last hour of nt. Thus for seventy years, she was known and honoieT asa follower of the Lamb, and member of his visible fam lily on earth Not an individual, is presumed in the circle of her acquaintance, has any doubt of the gen. uness of her piety. Her mental powers were more than ordinary; and she retained them, in remarka ale degree, till within two three of her last years Though her mind became then enfeebed, she enjoyed the use of her reason to her dying day. Her memmo ry richly stored with hymns and passages which to Dea Elijah Smith, of Belchertown, who died A. D. 177O, and at last Mir. Reuben Smith South Iadley who died A. h. 1797. One brother and three sisters survive herr of whom is 96 years of age, one 92, 90, 85. The total of their ages, added to hers, is 464 years The whole number of her decen- dants is children, all of whom lived until the young est had attained the age of 57-8 of them liV I.-c H. ~l. nx,l children, and of the fifth generation; making total of 266, of whom 2O4 are now living. Many of her prosterity professors of religion of whom are with Foreign Missions, under the direction of the A. mercan Board "As the days of a tree the days of my people. They shall bring forth fruit in old age; thy grave in full age as shock of corn cometh in its | season."

Has been determined on by large number of lib- eral gentlemen of that city, and to be edited by the subscriber, with an associate of distinguished literary attainnents. It is to be DAILY MORNING PAPER,de- voted principally to commerc and manufactures but including politics, literature and whatever else that may be interesting to intelligent men of business Ad- vertisments for the theare of lottery tickets, and of business to be transacted the Sabbath will be cluded. It is intended that the Shipping List shall not be surpassed in the country, especially will more thorough attention be paid to Eastern vessels than is usual in Ncw-YorlS. price current will be inserted as arrangements can be made to furnish one, which can be relied upon. The price is the same other New-York papers, $1O--A Journal will be is- sued SEMI-WEEKLY, containing the principal matter, at $4 To companies subscribing six papers seventh will be included gratis

 The gentlemen who have determined upon the es- tabshment of this paper have not done 1t with view to any pecuniary advantage. They have higher motive and one which has long interested the feelings of moral and religious men in Boston, New-York and other cities They ready to sacrifice money, to any amount which may be required. But it IS evi- dent that accomplish any valuable purpose wide circulation must be had. good subscription list has been obtained in NewYork, but the enterprise IS new in it's character and has to contend with many and powerful obstacles. To overcome these, no labor nor expense the part of the projectors or the Ed- tors will be spared. And they invite the hearty CO., of the country and its civil and literary institutions upon tlc basis of Christian religion and sound mor- ality.

 The publication will be commenced as soon as the details of preparation can be arranged And 1t IS re- uuested that names should be returned soon without York. DAVID HALE.

Iaisscovse riik Kss Msriosr,gA IeiieF to the cd. itors of the National InselligenccF, from a cores- csng of the increase of trade and intercourse between the Western country and the territories be- yondt:-

 FoRr OsAGE, May 10, 1897.

 "The Commissioners are just setting out for two months tour in the great prairies, to finish marking out the road" to New Mexico, upon the survey and examination that completed last fal- After the return, the Commissioners will make their final and full report of the Board which will be acc companied by very complete maps and chGrts and will, presume, be minute in its details and las I hope) satisfactory and interesting in all it's results- This work should have been entirely completed and reported last year, before the meeting of Congress but has been unavoidably delayed by the very unex- pected refusal of the Mexican Government to co-op- crate promptly in the measure.

 "TO judge from the preparations making should incline to think that the trade from this section of the Union to New Mexico, must be still increasng- Several fitting out, and will be on the road in few weeks; these, am informed, larger and better equipped, and carry out more value of merchandise than any which have heretofore gone to New Mexico. l have doubt this trade will con- tinue to increase till it settles down into well ganized and quite important branch of commerce, profitable to all concerned in it, and we'll worthy of the protection and fostering of the General Gov ernment, which doubt not it will receive in due time.o

 The Yearly Meeting of Friends commenced at Portsmouth, N. H. on Saturday, and was held on Sunday, at Newport, where it continued until We'd nesday. Anna Braithwaite and other celebrated Friends from England, attended the meeting.

 A Rev. gentleman (says the Providence Journal who has statedIy preached in this town to a large congregation for the last thnysx years has during that period, united in marriage 1Ge0 persons.

 The "Banksan Medal" of the London Horti- cultural society has been awarded to gentleman of Albany for barrel of American apples, embracing twenty varieties, forwarded to the society last winter Col. Leavenworth passed through Franklin, Missou- ri, on the 29th, of April, his way to the River Platte, to examine and fix place for military cantonment and the 1st of May four companies of United States Infantry arrived at Franklin, by water and proceeded on to join him.

FROM cLERGYMEN OF VARIOUS DENOMINATIONS.

 From the Rep. D.. Gri6in.-"I esteem Dr. Scots Family Bible, a e%anenty ny calculated to promote the for me to read daily the Notes and Observations with out becoming wiser and better man.'

 Rer. Asa Eaton, pastor of Christ Church, Boston. -" It is TREASURE WHICH EVERY FAMILY OUGHT TO POSSESS. For the success your undertaking you have my best wishes and fervent prayers"

 Rep. Dr. Joshua Bates, President ef M;ddlebury Coiiege.-" Sir, pleased with your proposals for publishing Scott's Family Bible, and sincerely wish you in your undertaking. have doubt that it will be well patronized by the religious public.'

 Rep. Daniel Shap pastor of the Sd Baptist Church, Boston.' The more it is read by pious Christians, the more extensive will be it's circuation.'

 Reu. Dr. Ba,d,oin, late pastor of the 2d Baptist Church, Boston, ""I feel free to say that in my esti nation it deservedly ranks among ables and best Commentaries. An the leading doctrines of Chris tanity as professed and maintained by many of the most eminent Reformers, are in judgment very hap pily illustrated and enforced"

 Reu Dr.. Dana-" Dr. Scott's Commentary, has merited and obtained distinguished popularity. The spirit which pervaes the work is excellent. It IS the meek, aectionate, healing yet faithful, spirit of the Gospel.

 Reu Joseph Emerson, Author of the Epanselical Primer" Six editions of this great work have been published in this county-I have had considerable opportunity to examine and compare specimens of all these six editions, and decidedly of opinion, that most people would greatly prefer ARNfSTRONG'S EDITION, now publishing in Boston. As the fold is octave, the volumes are not nearly 50 large the quarto editions; but the paper is finer and winter; the execution handsomer the print to appearance nearly as large; and it be turned to the light with much less nconyenence, 1t may perhaps be read with equal and pleasure. It has the advantage of be ing cheaper, less cumbersome, and more elegant.

 "ARMSTRONG'S EDITION, therefore, is the one which, most highly recommend for the use of families. It is peculiarly calculated to supcrsede the of large Bible; and in two respects it will answer better purpose merely for reading the scrip lures, it is less cumbersome, and may be read by several persons at the same tme.", @-ALSO- aSts Just received, and for Sale as above, A TREATISE ON SURVEYING. 1sp .not,r GSdMnaRrf, Fourth Improved Edition.-ALso, ES t...  Editors of papers who favor us with exchange wall confer particular obligation by inserting the a. bove once in their respective papers.

Of power'-we refer tO legislative caucussos,--we were conending for rather than for mensares, and were therefore acting in direct opposition to prOies sOns previously advanced. True, we had partiaity for certain men, and most ardenly desired their cess, at the late election but this pariay based upon the measures which these individuals would advocate in cOniradistnction to their opponents In supporting the national administration, and opposing the unprincpled faction,-made up from all parties, whig and tory, democrat and federal, bucktail and Cntonian, federation and ant-toleratou,-whicb has recently been "Organized' against it, have been accused of acting upon party" instead of "no par ty" principles. But in the pursuit of both these sures, we have done that which we have ever meant to do; never gave even an intimation that we meant to act contrary to the we have pur- sucd

 In the commencement of a volume of our pa- per, we can see no reason why we should apologize for any supposed alterations in general political course the past year, give any pledges to the course we shall pursue the coming year. We shall oppose the elevation of Gen. Jackson and his harpagons to the highest offices in the country- and so far the course of Mir. Adams and his cabi net is marked by attachment to domestic rather than foreign interests, so long shall yield them hearty support. We shall oppose legislative Caucusses, and every other similar which has tendency to destroy free and unbiased eec- ton; and so long present state constitution and the rights which it guarantees the people, respected by our state administration, so long will it command confidence, and receive from us cheerful and liberal support.

 Manutacturers' Meeting in Boston-A large & high ly respectable meeting of gentlemen friendly to the encouragement of domestic manufactures held in Boston the fifth inst. Many able addresses were made to the meeting, supporting the object for which they assembled & calculating in clear & forci bic manner the importance of strictly adhering to, and warmly supporting, the "American System' of pro- tecting industry, in preference to that of other country. We have given the speech of Mir. Otis entire; not because we consider it better than many others that delivered; but because Mir. Otis IS gentleman of age, of wealth, of experience, and has spent his life thus far in the midst of great commercial people; and consider opinions advan- ced by such entitled to great degree of credit The people of the Ncw-Engand Middle and Western States, have very deep interest in the question now pending, whether Congress shall establish such sys shall give safety and stability to American indus try, whether shall be left entirely to the mercy of older manufacturing and commercial nations, who strenuously persist in te adoption of such exclusively protect the industry and capital of their own people-whether shall be driven to the cessy of sending gold to England to purchase wool len goods,-a country which refuses to receive any important article of American growth industry, with the exception of Cotton-or whether such protec- ton shall be given to manufacturers shall ble them to supply our market with the article.

 This question is to be decided in the Senate at the next session of Congress- Whether the bill which passed the House in May last will pass the Senate is extremely doubtful. The measure is now, and has been, tavourite one with MT. Adams and Mir. Clay, and entirely devoid of principle the efforts made by the "Jackson Combination" that no means will be left untried to defeat the bi The people however will be heard upon this subject; and already has spirit of enquiry gone abroad among the rcemen of certain states deeply interested in the manufactu ring question: who were recently opposed to Mr. Ad- ams that augers we'll not only for the American Sys tem" but also for the reelection of present Chief Magistrate.

 The editor of the Hartford Times, paper of con- siderable circulation, and possessing good share of political influence abours almost necessarily to i'm press upon the public mind the opinion that Mr. Ad is unworthy of rust in the great republican family, and that Gen. Jackson, his competitor, possesses al- most infinitely more worth and patriotism than he does; and predicts that the time will shortly come when this will be owned and acknowledged by the republicans of Connecticut. Possibly should we make counter statement to this we should find many who would consider us worthy of credit, Mir. Wells finds to support his theory But the opinions of great men will ever be taken in preference either his ours, we shall give below certain extracts from late New York American relative to the comparative merits of Messrs. Adams and Jackson.-We shall begin with MT. Adams.

 Gen. Washington'S opinion of /. Q. AdamS.-In 1797, when he Minister Penipotentiary to Portu- gal, Washington sad-"I give it as my decided opin- "on that MT. Adams is the most valuable public char "actcr we have abroad, and there remains no doubt Con my mind that he will prove himself the abes of "all our diplomatic corps" At that period it will be rccollected that our foreign ministers, were Rufus King John Marshall, Chief Justice of the U. S. Su- preme Court c. c. Pinckney, and Eibridge Gerry. Mr. Adams first appointment as minister he received from President Washington in 179l.

 In 1907, he was appointed by President Jefferson, xstn;ser to Russia and how entirely he enjoyed the con6dence and friendship of Presidents Madison and :. fo Sav-hnt we shall

son President wNs tho single oiTeufnsanec that had shaken his faith, and made him fear that the Amcr can Republic was soon to follow the fate of an others and fall under military rule."

 We cannot, says the American, better comment up- on this opinion (which has not been denied, because it is well known that even though might be hoped to bear down the testimony to its truth of any n dividual even though respectable as GOv Coles, there are many others to whom Jefferson had expres- sed the apprehensOns,) than by copying the marks of the Richmond Whig, in relation to it.

 "We do (says the Whig) publish this opinion of Mir. Jefferson, with the hope the expectation of proselytism. We know too much of party spirit and party feelings to expect it. Fools to be vnced-the men of sense who support General Jack son, do it in the face of facts; in defiance of thou sand evidences of his unftness, imposing and overwhelming, than can be the opinion of Thomas Jefferson any other man. They have gone too far recede-or they infatuated to change, tho one should come from the dcad But there is a nu- class of meutrals, who have yet to de- csion between Adams and Jackson. Is not Mir. Jef. ferson's opinion entitled to weight and consideration with them Did not his information embrace the hs tory of the whole human family? Was not his experi and observation, the longest, the closest, the most profound and philosophical of any who has taken interest in the destinies of country? Will any doubt his devotion his country and human liberty every where Was not he the great apostle of Repub Lcanism Mir. Jefferson respected Gen. Jackson for his personal merts and honoured him for his public servicesyet did he think and say, and at time when he longer had any personal interest how the affairs of the United Stateswere managed, tat he oeced the prospect o his election to tue Presidency, bad omem tor the durability te Repblic---as evidence that the American people, like their Republican predecessors in Europe, ready to after military lender, and surrender their liberties to the first aspiring mili- tary chieftan who could dazzle them with the lustre of his glory"

 "The Litclfeld County Post, due some three weeks since, has not yet come to hand 1t has been suggest ed that there certain strctures on correspon- dent in that number of the paper, and the modest Ed itor has withheld his sheet in consequence. This we cannot believe of the courteous genenan-somc Post Master must have hooked it-or some thief must have broached the mailbag and laid violent hands that paper, the most valuable thing in it. Mir. Smith withhold his papers from us No indeed. He is sand to be the most honest man in all Litchfcd County devoid of low-cunnng, deceit hypocrisy, and all of evil-dvested of even that cursed bane which engendereth strife, ycleped party spirit We consider him one of the tarest specimens of Adams democra- cy--a strange congregation of WOrdS-v1negar and o--but Mr. Smith is honest. We wish he would send another paper in place of the missing, solen stray cd, lost number.'

 The above was published in the Hartford Times on the 4th inst Our readers will recolect the remarks upon the article in paper of the 7th. Inthe Times of the 11th the above is called "cvil request for missing number of the Pos," and the editor accuses of every thing vile, for noticing his "reques in the manner we did, In the Times of the 18th Mir. Wells boasts bravely of having detected in "pal pablo fasehood" for having asserted i'll our hrst mo- tice of h..i that the Post received by him, and the article in question read,' &1c: We did not con- sder the above civil paragraph" any proof the contrary rather considered it direct attempt at picking an editorial quarrel with It surely car res very much of that appearance the face of the it, and did act counter to human weakness in viewing it in that hgh especially since we were warn- ed some two or three months ago, that immediately after the close of the Legislature, attack would be made upon usby this paragon ofrepublcan excellence. We considered it impossible that the editor of the Times alone should miss hspaper, when all rsheets sent to Hartford covered in the same envelope; and we also considered it almost impossible that the whole package should be lost. Such however ap- pears to have been the fact; and had the editor reality cvilly requested' the number in question, 1t would have been forwarded and no {" ink shed' upon the subject.

 We again very civilly'' request Mir. Wells to con fine his attacks upon political questions which may be debated candidly. The common sense of the people is neither pleased nor eded by such indefinite attacks upon the character, political moral, of each other as individuals. Show wherefore you have dis- carded us from tho republican family point out our political heresy; give your views of political rectitude place your standard and stick to it, and we will either contend with you, publicly acknowledge your political infallbility.

 The Hat Shop of Messrs B. Kilbourn x Go. in the vicinity of this village, took fire Saturday night last fortunately the fire discovered and extin- guished without any material damage. We mention this circumstance because reports have gone abroad that the whole establishment destroyed; and the loss they have suffered by the fire, between $lOO and $200 is sufficient, without loss of custom from an impression that their business must be suspended for a season. The damage is nearly repaired, and their business will not be suspended on account oft.

 The Supreme Court of Errors commenced its an- nua session in this town Tuesday last. Present, Justices Hosmer, Dagget, Peters, and Lanman We know nothing of the quantity or importance of the business which will occupy the attention of the Court

 The Albany papers state that Strang, who has been some lime in prsou as the murderer of Mir. Whipple

 Sir Volumes, Royal Octav0,
full articles.article:
Si1 Volumes, Royal OctdU0, Being the eieuenth American Edto and complete in

 aN respects as the best London Edition THE following are Mir. $. T. Armstrongs terms as | published in the March Mo- (1827) of the Mis- sionary Herald.

 "In sheep binding, the price is $24; and in calf binding $50; from which prices very liberal DIs- again. The work IS comprised in six volumes, royal octave and well bound and lettered, it will be sold cheap, in proportion to the size of tIe pages the publications tho American Tract Society sold.

 "EKERY FOURTH SET GRATIS! That is, any person who takes three sets in sheep binding and pays for them the sum of $72 shall be entitled to set gratis; if the same sum of S72 is divided equally on all the four sets, it will reduce the amount payable for each of the four sets to $l8 instead of being discount of 9 per cent from the retail price. discount is made in 1he same proDor- tion on calf binding aud on ANY NUMBER OF COPIES, abore four, ho'osver largs."

 G57 The price at the LITCHFIELD BOOK STORE is $2l per single set, and SIS per set where four more taken in company.

 "The work contains the Old and New Testaments with copious Marginal References also valuable Notes explanatory of the Scriptures; and, lastly, the Pract- cal Observations. The work is so generally known all who acquainted with the publications of the present day, that is deemed unnecessary to enlarge upon it's contents.'

 The first edition of this work, the constant and in- creasng sale of which proves the high esteem in which it is deservedly hed) begun in 1788, and published in London, in numbers, consisted of 5000 copies; the second in 1805 of2 900 the third in l8lO of2 000 the fourth in 18l2 5000; and the edition is ote the largest work submitted that process. Besides these eight other editions, consisting, alto- gether, of 25,25O copies, were printed in the United States of America, from 1903 to 1819"-hiladelphiG Recorder.

full articles.article: SHARON, JUNE 12, 1897.

The Albany papers state that Strang, who has been some time in prison, the murderer of Mir. Whipple has acknowledged his guilt. The whole transaction exhibits one of the most determined acts of wifu mur der we ever heard of Intent on his victim, this mon- ster in human shape had previously practsed firing at ,G2rk through glass, ascertain whether ball would glance upon this substance. The evening which he committed the murder, he called at several public pla- ces probably to destroy any suspicion which might at tach to him after the contemplated act he then took his rife, climbed upon shed which gave him com manding view ofhs victim, andaeok the fatal aim A r ter having fed to some dasResahd secured hisrife he returned to the vicinity Mir. Whippe's house, and was empanneled of the coronersjury which sat ,.on the murdered body! Strang also accuses Mrs. Whippe of being accessary to the act whether to n- crease the misery he has already brought upon the family, or because such is the fact We have not been able to learn.
